A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.

An A-module is an abelian group M, together with an exterior multiplication A x M -> M, (a, x) -> a.x that satisfies the vector space axioms: a.(x+y) = a.x + a.y, (a+b).x = a.x + b.x, a.(b.x) = (ab).x, 1.x = x for elements a, b in A, x, y in M.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called simple if there exists an element $\alpha \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha)$. The degree $[K(\alpha): K]$ is referred to as the degree of $\alpha$ over $K$.

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
A splitting field $L$ of a polynomial $f \\(in K[X]\\) with coefficients in a field $K$ is a field extension $L / K$ where the polynomial $f$ splits into linear factors.
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A free A-module is a specialization of an A-module because it inherits all properties of an A-module and additionally has a basis, making it a specific type of A-module.
